*use_application_default_credentials*:::

Use application default credentials to authenticate to the cluster API server.


*use_client_certificate*:::

Use the cluster's client certificate to authenticate to the cluster API server.


_proxy_::


*address*:::

The hostname or IP address of your proxy server.


*password*:::

If your proxy requires authentication, the password to use when connecting.


*port*:::

The port to use when connected to your proxy server.


*type*:::

The type of proxy you are using.  Supported proxy types are: [http, http_no_tunnel, socks4, socks5].


*username*:::

If your proxy requires authentication, the username to use when connecting.

config.description:
A configuration is a set of properties that govern the behavior of gcloud
and other tools in the Cloud SDK. The SDK provides a configuration named
`default` whose initial properties are set when you run the `gcloud init`
command. You can create any number of additional named configurations using
`gcloud init` or `gcloud config configurations create`, and switch between
configurations using `gcloud config configurations activate`.

gcloud supports several flags that have the same effect as properties in
a configuration (for example, gcloud supports both the `--project` flag and
`project` property). Properties differ from flags in that flags affect command
behavior on a per-invocation basis. Properties allow you to maintain the same
settings across command executions.

For more information on configurations, see `gcloud topic configurations`.

## AVAILABLE PROPERTIES

{properties}
config.name: config

sections.properties:
_core_::


*account*:::

The account gcloud should use for authentication.  You can run `gcloud auth list` to see the accounts you currently have available.


*custom_ca_certs_file*:::

Absolute path to a custom CA cert file.


*default_regional_backend_service*:::

If True, backend services in `gcloud compute backend-services` will be regional by default. The `--global` flag will be required for global backend services.


*disable_color*:::

If True, color will not be used when printing messages in the terminal.


*disable_prompts*:::

If True, the default answer will be assumed for all user prompts.  For any prompts that require user input, an error will be raised. This is the equivalent of using the global `--quiet` flag.


*disable_usage_reporting*:::

If True, anonymous statistics on SDK usage will not be collected.  This is value is set based on your choices during installation, but can be changed at any time.  For more information, see: https://cloud.google.com/sdk/usage-statistics


*log_http*:::

If True, log HTTP requests and responses to the logs.  You may need to adjust your `verbosity` setting if you want to see in the terminal, otherwise it is available in the log files.


*max_log_days*:::

Maximum number of days to retain log files before deleting. If set to 0, turns off log garbage collection and does not delete log files. If unset, defaults to 30.


*pass_credentials_to_gsutil*:::

If True, pass the configured Cloud SDK authentication to gsutil.


*project*:::

The project id of the Cloud Platform project to operate on by default.  This can be overridden by using the global `--project` flag.


*trace_token*:::

Token used to route traces of service requests for investigation of issues. This token will be provided by Google support.


*user_output_enabled*:::

If False, messages to the user and command output on both standard output and standard error will be suppressed.


*verbosity*:::

The default logging verbosity for gcloud commands.  This is the equivalent of using the global `--verbosity` flag.


_app_::


*cloud_build_timeout*:::

The timeout, in seconds, to wait for Docker builds to complete during deployments. All Docker builds now use the Container Builder API.


*stop_previous_version*:::

If True, when deploying a new version of a service, the previously deployed version is stopped. If False, older versions must be stopped manually.


_component_manager_::


*additional_repositories*:::

A comma separated list of additional repositories to check for components.  This property is automatically managed by the `gcloud components repositories` commands.


*disable_update_check*:::

If True, the Cloud SDK will not automatically check for updates.


_compute_::


*region*:::

The default region to use when working with regional Compute Engine resources. When a `--region` flag is required but not provided, the command will fall back to this value, if set. To see valid choices, run `gcloud compute regions list`.


*zone*:::

The default zone to use when working with zonal Compute Engine resources. When a `--zone` flag is required but not provided, the command will fall back to this value, if set. To see valid choices, run `gcloud compute zones list`.


_container_::


*build_timeout*:::

The timeout, in seconds, to wait for container builds to complete.


*cluster*:::

The name of the cluster to use by default when working with Container Engine.


*use_application_default_credentials*:::

Use application default credentials to authenticate to the cluster API server.


*use_client_certificate*:::

Use the cluster's client certificate to authenticate to the cluster API server.


_proxy_::


*address*:::

The hostname or IP address of your proxy server.


*password*:::

If your proxy requires authentication, the password to use when connecting.


*port*:::

The port to use when connected to your proxy server.


*type*:::

The type of proxy you are using.  Supported proxy types are: [http, http_no_tunnel, socks4, socks5].


*username*:::

If your proxy requires authentication, the username to use when connecting.

create.capsule: Create a cluster for running containers.
create.description: Create a cluster for running containers.

--additional-zones.description:
The set of additional zones in which the specified node footprint should be
replicated. All zones must be in the same region as the cluster's primary zone.
If additional-zones is not specified, all nodes will be in the cluster's primary
zone.

Note that `NUM_NODES` nodes will be created in each zone, such that if you
specify `--num-nodes=4` and choose one additional zone, 8 nodes will be created.

Multiple locations can be specified, separated by commas. For example:

  $ {command} example-cluster --zone us-central1-a --additional-zones us-central1-b,us-central1-c
--additional-zones.name: --additional-zones

--async.description: Don't wait for the operation to complete.
--async.name: --async

--cluster-ipv4-cidr.description: The IP address range for the pods in this cluster in CIDR notation (e.g. 10.0.0.0/14). Due to kube-proxy limitations, this range must be a subset of the 10.0.0.0/8 space. Defaults to server-specified
--cluster-ipv4-cidr.name: --cluster-ipv4-cidr

--disable-addons.description: List of cluster addons to disable. Options are HttpLoadBalancing, HorizontalPodAutoscaling
--disable-addons.name: --disable-addons

--disk-size.description: Size in GB for node VM boot disks. Defaults to 100GB.
--disk-size.name: --disk-size

--enable-cloud-endpoints.description: Automatically enable Google Cloud Endpoints to take advantage of API management features.
--enable-cloud-endpoints.name: --enable-cloud-endpoints

--enable-cloud-logging.description: Automatically send logs from the cluster to the Google Cloud Logging API.
--enable-cloud-logging.name: --enable-cloud-logging

--enable-cloud-monitoring.description: Automatically send metrics from pods in the cluster to the Google Cloud Monitoring API. VM metrics will be collected by Google Compute Engine regardless of this setting.
--enable-cloud-monitoring.name: --enable-cloud-monitoring

--image-type.description:
The image type to use for the cluster. Defaults to server-specified.

Image Type specifies the base OS that the nodes in the cluster will run on.
If an image type is specified, that will be assigned to the cluster and all
future upgrades will use the specified image type. If it is not specified the
server will pick the default image type.

The default image type and the list of valid image types are available
using the following command.

  $ gcloud container get-server-config
--image-type.name: --image-type

--machine-type.description: The type of machine to use for nodes. Defaults to server-specified
--machine-type.name: --machine-type

--max-nodes-per-pool.description: The maximum number of nodes to allocate per default initial node pool. Container engine will automatically create enough nodes pools such that each node pool contains less than --max-nodes-per-pool nodes. Defaults to 1000 nodes, but can be set as low as 100 nodes per pool on initial create.
--max-nodes-per-pool.name: --max-nodes-per-pool

--network.description: The Compute Engine Network that the cluster will connect to. Google Container Engine will use this network when creating routes and firewalls for the clusters. Defaults to the 'default' network.
--network.name: --network

--node-labels.description:
Applies the given kubernetes labels on all nodes in the new node-pool. Example:

  $ {command} example-cluster --node-labels=label-a=value1,label-2=value2

New nodes, including ones created by resize or recreate, will have these labels
on the kubernetes API node object and can be used in nodeSelectors.
See http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/node-selection/ for examples.
--node-labels.name: --node-labels

--num-nodes.description: The number of nodes to be created in each of the cluster's zones.
--num-nodes.name: --num-nodes

--password.description: The password to use for cluster auth. Defaults to a server-specified randomly-generated string.
--password.name: --password

--scopes.description:
Specifies scopes for the node instances. The project's default
service account is used. Examples:

  $ {command} example-cluster --scopes https://www.googleapis.com/auth/devstorage.read_only

  $ {command} example-cluster --scopes bigquery,storage-rw,compute-ro

Multiple SCOPEs can specified, separated by commas. The scopes
necessary for the cluster to function properly (compute-rw, storage-ro),
are always added, even if not explicitly specified.

SCOPE can be either the full URI of the scope or an alias.
Available aliases are:

sections.DESCRIPTION:
Resize an existing cluster to a provided size.

If you have multiple node pools, you must specify which node pool to resize by
using the --node-pool flag. You are not required to use the flag if you have
a single node pool.

When increasing the size of a container cluster, the new instances are created
with the same configuration as the existing instances.
Existing pods are not moved onto the new instances,
but new pods (such as those created by resizing a replication controller)
will be scheduled onto the new instances.

When decreasing a cluster, the pods that are scheduled on the instances being
removed will be killed. If your pods are being managed by a replication
controller, the controller will attempt to reschedule them onto the remaining
instances. If your pods are not managed by a replication controller,
they will not be restarted.
Note that when resizing down, instances running pods and instances without pods
are not differentiated. Resize will pick instances to remove at random.

upgrade.capsule: Upgrade the Kubernetes version of an existing container cluster.
upgrade.description: Upgrade the Kubernetes version of an existing container cluster.

--async.description: Don't wait for the operation to complete.
--async.name: --async

--cluster-version.description:
The Kubernetes version to use for the master or nodes. Defaults to server-specified.

The default Kubernetes version are available using the following command.

  $ gcloud container get-server-config
--cluster-version.name: --cluster-version

--image-type.description:
The image type to use for the cluster/node pool. Defaults to server-specified.

Image Type specifies the base OS that the nodes in the cluster/node pool will run on.
If an image type is specified, that will be assigned to the cluster/node pool and all
future upgrades will use the specified image type. If it is not specified the
server will pick the default image type.

The default image type and the list of valid image types are available
using the following command.

  $ gcloud container get-server-config
--image-type.name: --image-type

--master.description: Upgrade the cluster's master to the latest version of Kubernetes supported on Container Engine. Nodes cannot be upgraded at the same time as the master.
--master.name: --master

--wait.description: DEPRECATED, use --no-async. Poll the operation for completion after issuing a create request.
--wait.name: --wait

upgrade.name: upgrade

positionals.description: The name of the cluster to upgrade.
positionals.name: name

sections.DESCRIPTION:
Upgrades the Kubernetes version of an existing container cluster.

This command upgrades the Kubernetes version of the *nodes* of a cluster.
The Kubernetes version of the cluster's *master* is periodically upgraded
automatically as new releases are available.

*By running this command, all of the cluster's nodes will be deleted and*
*recreated one at a time.* While persistent Kubernetes resources, such as
pods backed by replication controllers, will be rescheduled onto new nodes,
a small cluster may experience a few minutes where there are insufficient
nodes available to run all of the scheduled Kubernetes resources.

*Please ensure that any data you wish to keep is stored on a persistent*
*disk before upgrading the cluster.* Ephemeral Kubernetes resources--in
particular, pods without replication controllers--will be lost, while
persistent Kubernetes resources will get rescheduled.
sections.EXAMPLES:
Upgrade the nodes of <cluster> to the Kubernetes version of the cluster's
master.

  $ upgrade <cluster>

Upgrade the nodes of <cluster> to Kubernetes version x.y.z.

  $ upgrade <cluster> --cluster-version "x.y.z"

create.name: create

sections.DESCRIPTION:
*create* facilitates the creation of a node pool in a Google
Container Engine cluster. A variety of options exists to customize the
node configuration and the number of nodes created.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To create a new node pool "node-pool-1" with the default options in the
cluster "sample-cluster", run:

  $ create node-pool-1 --cluster=example-cluster

The new node pool will show up in the cluster after all the nodes have
been provisioned.

To create a node pool with 5 nodes, run:

  $ create node-pool-1 --cluster=example-cluster --num-nodes=5

sections.DESCRIPTION: *delete* deletes a node pool from a Google Container Engine cluster.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To delete the "node-pool-1" node pool from the cluster

list.capsule: List jobs in a project.
list.description:
List jobs in a project. An optional filter can be used to constrain the jobs
returned. Filters are case-sensitive and have the following syntax:

  [field = value] AND [field [= value]] ...

where `field` is `status.state` or `labels.[KEY]`, and `[KEY]` is a label
key. `value` can be ```*``` to match all values. `status.state` can be either
`ACTIVE` or `INACTIVE`. Only the logical `AND` operator is supported;
space-separated items are treated as having an implicit `AND` operator.

## EXAMPLES

To see the list of all jobs, run:

  $ list

To see a list of all active jobs in cluster `my_cluster` with a label of
`env=staging`, run:

  $ list --filter='status.state = ACTIVE AND placement.clusterName = my_cluster AND labels.env = staging'

--cluster.description: Restrict to the jobs of this Dataproc cluster.
--cluster.name: --cluster

--sort-by.name: --sort-by

## EXAMPLES

To submit a Hadoop job that runs the main class of a jar, run:

 $ hadoop --cluster my_cluster --jar my_jar.jar arg1 arg2

To submit a Hadoop job that runs a specific class of a jar, run:

  $ hadoop --cluster my_cluster --class org.my.main.Class --jars my_jar1.jar,my_jar2.jar arg1 arg2

To submit a Hadoop job that runs a jar that is already on the cluster, run:

  $ hadoop --cluster my_cluster --jar file:///usr/lib/hadoop-op/hadoop-op-examples.jar wordcount gs://my_bucket/my_file.txt gs://my_bucket/output

To update the label 'customer=ackme' to 'customer=acme', run:

  $ update job_id --update-labels=customer=acme

To remove the label whose key is 'customer', run:

  $ update job_id --remove-labels=customer

## EXAMPLES

To learn about the types of jobs that can be submitted, run:

To view the output of a job as it runs, run:

To cancel an active job, run:

To view the details of a job, run:

To see the list of all jobs, run:

To delete the record of an inactive job, run:

list.capsule: View the list of all operations.
list.description:
View a list of operations in a project. An optional filter can be used to
constrain the operations returned. Filters are case-sensitive and have the
following syntax:

  field = value [AND [field = value]] ...

where `field` is either of `status.state` or `labels.[KEY]`, where `[KEY]` is
a label key. `value` can be ```*``` to match all values. `status.state` is
one of: `PENDING`, `ACTIVE`, `DONE`. Only the logical `AND` operator is
supported; space-separated items are treated as having an implicit `AND`
operator.

## EXAMPLES

To see the list of all operations, run:

  $ list

To see the list of all active operations in a cluster named mycluster, run:

  $ list --filter='status.state = RUNNING AND clusterName = mycluster'

To see a list of all pending operations the label `env=staging` on cluster `mycluster`, run:

  $ list --filter='status.state = PENDING  AND labels.env = staging AND clusterName = mycluster'

--cluster.description: Restrict to the operations of this Dataproc cluster. This flag is ignored when --filter is specified. The equivalent term in a --filter expression is: `clusterName = myclustername`
--cluster.name: --cluster

--filter.description: Apply _EXPRESSION_ to select resource items to list.
--filter.name: --filter

--limit.description: The maximum number of resources to list.
--limit.name: --limit

--page-size.description: The service resource list page size.
--page-size.name: --page-size

--sort-by.description: A comma-separated list of field key names to sort by.
--sort-by.name: --sort-by

--state-filter.description: Filter by cluster state. This flag is ignored when --filter is specified. The equivalent term in a --filter expression is: `status.state = ACTIVE`
--state-filter.name: --state-filter

list.name: list

debug.capsule: Commands for interacting with the Cloud Debugger.

logpoints.capsule: Commands for interacting with Cloud Debugger logpoints.

create.capsule: Create debug logpoints.
create.description: Create debug logpoints.

--condition.description:
A condition to restrict when the log output is generated. When the
logpoint is hit, the condition will be evaluated, and the log output
will be generated only if the condition is true.
--condition.name: --condition

--log-level.description: The logging level to use when producing the log message.
--log-level.name: --log-level

--wait.description:
The number of seconds to wait to ensure that no error is returned
from a debugger agent when creating the logpoint. When a logpoint
is created, there will be a delay before the agents see and apply
the logpoint. Until at least one agent has attempted to
enable the logpoint, it cannot be determined if the logpoint is
valid.
--wait.name: --wait

create.name: create

positionals.description:
The logpoint location. Locations are of
the form FILE:LINE, where FILE can be simply the file name, or the
file name preceded by enough path components to differentiate it
from other files with the same name. It is an error to provide a
file name that is not unique in the debug target.
positionals.name: location

positionals.description:
A format string which will be logged every time the logpoint
location is executed. If the string contains curly braces ('{' and
'}'), any text within the curly braces will be interpreted as a
run-time expression in the debug target's language, which will be
evaluated when the logpoint is hit.

The value of the expression will then replace the {} expression in
the resulting log output. For example, if you specify the format
string "a={a}, b={b}", and the logpoint is hit when local variable
a is 1 and b is 2, the resulting log output would be "a=1, b=2".
positionals.name: log-format-string

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command adds a debug logpoint to a debug target. Logpoints add
logging to your running service without changing your code or
restarting your application. When you create a logpoint, the message
you specify will be added to your logs whenever any instance of your
service executes the specified line of code.

The default lifetime of a logpoint is 24 hours from creation, and the
output will go to the standard log for the programming language of the
target (java.logging for Java, logging.* for Python, etc.)

delete.description:
This command deletes logpoints from a Cloud Debugger debug target. It will
ask for confirmation before deleting any logpoints. To suppress confirmation,
use the global --quiet option.

--all-users.description:
If set, any location regexp will match logpoints from all users,
rather than only logpoints created by the current user. This flag is
not required when specifying the exact ID of a logpoint created by
another user.
--all-users.name: --all-users

--include-inactive.description:
If set, any location regexp will also match inactive logpoints,
rather than only logpoints which have not expired. This flag is
not required when specifying the exact ID of an inactive logpoint.
--include-inactive.name: --include-inactive

--location.description:
A regular expression to match against logpoint
locations. All logpoints matching this value will be
deleted.  You may specify --location multiple times.

EXAMPLE:

  {command} \
      --location foo.py:[1-3] --location bar.py:4
--location.name: --location

delete.name: delete

positionals.description:
Zero or more logpoint resource identifiers. The specified
logpoints will be deleted.
positionals.name: ids

list.capsule: List debug logpoints.
list.description: List debug logpoints.

--all-users.description: If false, display only logpoints created by the current user.
--all-users.name: --all-users

--filter.description: Apply _EXPRESSION_ to select resource items to list.
--filter.name: --filter

--include-inactive.description:
Include logpoints which failed or expired in the last
INCLUDE_INACTIVE seconds. If the value is "unlimited", all failed
or expired logpoints will be included.
--include-inactive.name: --include-inactive

--limit.description: The maximum number of resources to list.
--limit.name: --limit

--location.description:
A regular expression to match against logpoint
locations. All logpoints matching this value will be
listed.  You may specify --location multiple times.

EXAMPLE:

  {command} \
      --location foo.py:[1-3] --location bar.py:4
--location.name: --location

--page-size.description: The service resource list page size.
--page-size.name: --page-size

--sort-by.description: A comma-separated list of field key names to sort by.
--sort-by.name: --sort-by

Zero or more logpoint resource identifiers. The specified
logpoints will be listed.
positionals.name: ids

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command displays a list of the active debug logpoints for a
Cloud Debugger debug target.

logpoints.description:
Logpoints allow you to inject logging into running services without
restarting or interfering with the normal function of the service. Log output
will be sent to the appropriate log for the target's environment.
On App Engine, for example, output will go to the request log.

--target.description:
The debug target. It may be a target ID or name obtained from
'debug targets list', or it may be a regular expression uniquely
specifying a debuggee based on its description or name. For App
Engine projects, if not specified, the default target is
the most recent deployment of the default module and version.
--target.name: --target

logpoints.name: logpoints

sections.EXAMPLES:
The following command would log the value of the "name" attribute
of the "product" variable whenever any request executes line 123 of
the file product.py:

    $ logpoints create product.py:123               "No description for {product.name}"

The log output will appear wherever explicit logging output from your
program is normally written. For example, for an App Engine Standard
application, the output would appear in the request log.

If you want to log output only when certain runtime conditions are met,
you can add a "--condition" option:

    $ logpoints create product.py:123               "Suspicious price: {product.name} costs {price}"               --condition "price < .50"

Logpoints remain active for 24 hours after creation. If you want to
disable a logpoint, use the logpoints delete command:

    $ logpoints delete product.*

The above command would delete all logpoints in any file whose name
begins with "product". If you want to delete only a single logpoint, you
should first determine the logpoint ID using the logpoints list command,
then delete that specific ID:

    $ logpoints list
    ID                        LOCATION    ...
    567890abcdef1-1234-56789  product.py:123  ...
    $ logpoints delete 567890abcdef1-1234-56789

For App Engine services, logpoint resources include the "logQuery"
property, which is suitable for use with the "gcloud beta logging read"
command. You can save this property's value and use it to read logs from
the command line:

    $ log_query=$(logpoints create product.py:123               "No description for {product.name}" --format="value(logQuery)")
    $ gcloud beta logging read "$log_query"

snapshots.capsule: Commands for interacting with Cloud Debugger snapshots.

create.capsule: Create debug snapshots.
create.description: Create debug snapshots.

--condition.description:
A condition to restrict when the snapshot is taken. When the
snapshot location is executed, the condition will be evaluated, and
the snapshot will be generated only if the condition is true.
--condition.name: --condition

--expression.description:
An expression to evaluate when the snapshot is taken. You may
specify --expression multiple times.
--expression.name: --expression

--wait.description:
The number of seconds to wait to ensure that no error is returned
from a debugger agent when creating the snapshot. When a snapshot
is created, there will be a delay before the agents see and apply
the snapshot. Until at least one agent has attempted to
enable the snapshot, it cannot be determined if the snapshot is
valid.
--wait.name: --wait

create.name: create

positionals.description:
The location where the snapshot should be taken. Locations are of
the form FILE:LINE, where FILE can be simply the file name, or the
file name preceded by enough path components to differntiate it from
other files with the same name. If the file name is not unique in
the debug target, the behavior is unspecified.
positionals.name: location

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command creates a debug snapshot on a Cloud Debugger debug
target. Snapshots allow you to capture stack traces and local
variables from your running service without interfering with normal
operations.

When any instance of the target executes the snapshot location, the
optional condition expression is evaluated. If the result is true
(or if there is no condition), the instance captures the current
thread state and reports it back to Cloud Debugger. Once any instance
captures a snapshot, the snapshot is marked as completed, and it
will not be captured again.

You can most easily view snapshot results in the developer console. It
is also possible to inspect snapshot results with the "snapshots
describe" command.

delete.description:
This command deletes snapshots from a Cloud Debugger debug target. It will
ask for confirmation before deleting any snapshots. To suppress confirmation,
use the global --quiet option.

--all-users.description:
If set, matching snapshots from all users will be deleted, rather
than only snapshots created by the current user.
--all-users.name: --all-users

--include-inactive.description:
If set, also delete snapshots which have been completed. By default,
only pending snapshots will be deleted.
--include-inactive.name: --include-inactive

--location.description:
A regular expression to match against snapshot
locations. All snapshots matching this value will be
deleted.  You may specify --location multiple times.

EXAMPLE:

  {command} \
      --location foo.py:[1-3] --location bar.py:4
--location.name: --location

delete.name: delete

positionals.description:
Zero or more snapshot resource identifiers. The specified
snapshots will be deleted.
positionals.name: ids

human-readable.

EXAMPLE:

  {command} \

sections.DESCRIPTION:

wait.capsule: Wait for debug snapshots to complete.
wait.description: Wait for debug snapshots to complete.

--all.description:
If set, wait for all of the specified snapshots to complete, instead of
waiting for any one of them to complete.
--all.name: --all

--all-users.description:
If set, wait for matching snapshots from all users, rather than

--filter.description: Apply _EXPRESSION_ to select resource items to list.
--filter.name: --filter

--limit.description: The maximum number of resources to list.

--location.description:

locations. The command will wait for any snapshots matching these

EXAMPLE:

--location.name: --location

--page-size.description: The service resource list page size.

--sort-by.description: A comma-separated list of field key names to sort by.
--sort-by.name: --sort-by

--timeout.description:
Maximum number of seconds to wait for a snapshot to complete. By
default, wait indefinitely.
--timeout.name: --timeout

--uri.description: Print a list of resource URIs instead of the default output.
--uri.name: --uri

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command waits for one or more snapshots on a Cloud Debugger debug

Commands to interact with debug targets. A debug target can be an App Engine
module version or any other entity enabled for use with the cloud debugger.
targets.name: targets

sections.EXAMPLES:
To view all available debug targets, run:

    $ targets list

debug.description:
Commands that allow interacting with the Cloud Debugger to list and
manipulate debug targets, snapshots, and logpoints.
debug.name: debug

sections.EXAMPLES:
To view all available debug targets, run:

    $ debug targets list
    NAME           ID             DESCRIPTION
    default-test   gcp:1234:5678  myproject-test-9876543
    default-test2  gcp:9012:3456  myproject-test2-1234567

To create a snapshot in a for a particular target:

    $ debug snapshots create --target=default-test foo.py:12
    ...

Note that if there is not a target with the exact name or ID
specified, the target is treated as a regular expression to match
against the name or description:

    $ debug snapshots create --target=test foo.py:12
    ERROR: (gcloud.beta.debug.snapshots.create) Multiple possible
    targets found.
    Use the --target option to select one of the following targets:
        default-test
        default-test2

In the above case, "test" matches both targets' names. Specifying
'test$' would match only "default-test" (by name), while "9876" would
match "default-test" by description.

This command will update a deployment with the new config file provided.
Different policies for create, update, and delete policies can be specified.

--async.description: Return immediately and print information about the Operation in progress rather than waiting for the Operation to complete. (default=False)
--async.name: --async

--config.description: Filename of config which specifies resources to deploy. Required unless launching an already-previewed update to this deployment.
--config.name: --config

--create-policy.description: Create policy for resources that have changed in the update.
--create-policy.name: --create-policy

--delete-policy.description: Delete policy for resources that will change as part of an update or delete. DELETE deletes the resource while ABANDON just removes the resource reference from the deployment.
--delete-policy.name: --delete-policy

--description.description: The new description of the deployment.
--description.name: --description

--preview.description: Preview the requested update without making any changes to theunderlying resources. (default=False)
--preview.name: --preview

--properties.description: A comma seperated, key=value, map to be used when deploying a template file directly.
--properties.name: --properties

update.name: update

positionals.description: Deployment name.
positionals.name: deployment-name

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command will update a deployment with the new config file provided.
Different policies for create, update, and delete policies can be specified.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To update an existing deployment with a new config file, run:

  $ update my-deployment --config new_config.yaml

To preview an update to an existing deployment without actually modifying the resources, run:

  $ update my-deployment --config new_config.yaml --preview

To apply an update that has been previewed, provide the name of the previewed deployment, and no config file:

  $ update my-deployment

To specify different create, update, or delete policies, include any subset of the following flags;

  $ update my-deployment --config new_config.yaml --create-policy ACQUIRE --delete-policy ABANDON

To perform an update without waiting for the operation to complete, run:

  $ update my-deployment --config new_config.yaml --async

deployments.description: Commands to create, update, delete, and examine deployments of resources.
deployments.name: deployments

sections.DESCRIPTION: Commands to create, update, delete, and examine deployments of resources.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To create a deployment, run:

  $ deployments create my-deployment --config config.yaml

To update a deployment, run:

  $ deployments update my-deployment --config new_config.yaml

To stop a deployment create or update in progress, run:

  $ deployments stop my-deployment

To cancel a previewed create or update, run:

  $ deployments cancel-preview my-deployment

To delete a deployment, run:

  $ deployments delete my-deployment

To view the details of a deployment, run:

  $ deployments describe my-deployment

To see the list of all deployments, run:

  $ deployments list

create.capsule: Create a Cloud DNS managed-zone.

This command creates a Cloud DNS managed-zone.

export.capsule: Export your record-sets into a file.
export.description:
This command exports the record-sets contained within the specified
managed-zone into a file.

--zone.description: Name of the managed-zone whose record-sets you want to manage.
--zone.name: --zone

--zone-file-format.description: Indicates that records-file should be in the zone file format.
--zone-file-format.name: --zone-file-format

export.name: export

positionals.description: File to which record-sets should be exported.
positionals.name: records-file

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command exports the record-sets contained within the specified
managed-zone into a file.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To export record-sets into a yaml file, run:

  $ export YAML_RECORDS_FILE -z MANAGED_ZONE

To import record-sets into a zone file, run:

  $ export ZONE_FILE --zone-file-format -z MANAGED_ZONE

import.description:
This command imports record-sets contained within the specified record-sets
file into your managed-zone. Note that NS records for the origin of the zone,
and the SOA NS field, are not imported since name-servers are managed by
Cloud DNS. By default, record-sets cannot be imported if there are any
conflicts. A conflict exists if an existing record-set has the same name and
type as a record-set that is being imported. In contrast, if the
--delete-all-existing flag is used, the imported record-sets will replace all
the records-sets currently in the managed-zone.

--delete-all-existing.description: Indicates that all existing record-sets should be deleted before importing the record-sets in the records-file.
--delete-all-existing.name: --delete-all-existing

--replace-origin-ns.description: Indicates that NS records for the origin of a zone should be imported if defined
--replace-origin-ns.name: --replace-origin-ns

--zone.description: Name of the managed-zone whose record-sets you want to manage.
--zone.name: --zone

--zone-file-format.description: Indicates that the records-file is in the zone file format.
--zone-file-format.name: --zone-file-format

import.name: import

positionals.description: File from which record-sets should be imported.
positionals.name: records-file

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command imports record-sets contained within the specified record-sets
file into your managed-zone. Note that NS records for the origin of the zone,
and the SOA NS field, are not imported since name-servers are managed by
Cloud DNS. By default, record-sets cannot be imported if there are any
conflicts. A conflict exists if an existing record-set has the same name and
type as a record-set that is being imported. In contrast, if the
--delete-all-existing flag is used, the imported record-sets will replace all
the records-sets currently in the managed-zone.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To import record-sets from a yaml record-sets file, run:

  $ import YAML_RECORDS_FILE -z MANAGED_ZONE

To import record-sets from a zone file, run:

  $ import ZONE_FILE --zone-file-format -z MANAGED_ZONE

To replace all the record-sets in your zone with records from a yaml
file, run:

  $ import YAML_RECORDS_FILE --delete-all-existing -z MANAGED_ZONE

To see the list of all record-sets in my_zone, run:

  $ list -z my_zone

To see the list of first 10 record-sets in my_zone, run:

  $ list -z my_zone --limit=10

To see the list of 'my.zone.com.' record-sets in my_zone, run:

  $ list -z my_zone --name="my.zone.com."

To see the list of 'my.zone.com.' CNAME record-sets in my_zone, run:

  $ list -z my_zone --name="my.zone.com." --type="CNAME"

To remove a TXT record with multiple data values, run:

  $ remove -z MANAGED_ZONE --name my.domain. --ttl 2345 --type TXT "Hello world" "Bye world"

transaction.description: Make scriptable and transactional changes to your record-sets.

--transaction-file.description: Path of the file which contains the transaction.
--transaction-file.name: --transaction-file

transaction.name: transaction

sections.DESCRIPTION: Make scriptable and transactional changes to your record-sets.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To start a transaction, run:

  $ transaction start

To append a record-set addition to the transaction, run:

  $ transaction add --name RECORD_SET_NAME --ttl TTL --type TYPE DATA

To append a record-set removal to the transaction, run:

  $ transaction remove --name RECORD_SET_NAME --ttl TTL --type TYPE DATA

To look at the details of the transaction, run:

  $ transaction describe

To delete the transaction, run:

  $ transaction abort

To execute the transaction, run:

  $ transaction execute

record-sets.description: Manage the record-sets within your managed-zones.
record-sets.name: record-sets

sections.DESCRIPTION: Manage the record-sets within your managed-zones.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To import record-sets from a BIND zone file, run:

  $ record-sets import -z MANAGED_ZONE  --zone-file-format ZONE_FILE

To export record-sets in yaml format, run:

  $ record-sets export -z MANAGED_ZONE

To see how to make scriptable changes to your record-sets through transactions, run:

  $ record-sets transaction -z MANAGED_ZONE

To see change details or list of all changes, run:

  $ record-sets changes -z MANAGED_ZONE

To see the list of all record-sets, run:

  $ record-sets list -z MANAGED_ZONE

dns.description:
This set of commands allows you to create and maintain managed-zones and their
record-sets.

## EXAMPLES

To see how to create and maintain managed-zones, run:

  $ dns managed-zones --help

To see how to maintain the record-sets within a managed-zone, run:

  $ dns record-sets --help

To display Cloud DNS related information for your project, run:

  $ dns project-info describe --help
dns.name: dns

docker.capsule: Provides the docker CLI access to the Google Container Registry.
docker.description: Provides the docker CLI access to the Google Container Registry.

--authorize-only.description: Configure docker authorization only, do not launch the docker command-line.
--authorize-only.name: --authorize-only

--docker-host.description: The URL to connect to Docker Daemon. Format: tcp://host:port or unix:///path/to/socket.
--docker-host.name: --docker-host

--server.description: The address of the Google Cloud Registry.
--server.name: --server

docker.name: docker

positionals.description: Arguments to pass to docker.
positionals.name: docker-args

sections.DESCRIPTION:
The docker sub-command of gcloud wraps docker commands, so that
gcloud can inject the appropriate fresh authentication token into
requests that interact with the docker registry.  As commands are
simply passed through to docker, see
[](http://docs.docker.com/reference/commandline/cli/) for a full
reference of command-line options that can be supplied after the --.

For more information please visit [](https://gcr.io/)
sections.EXAMPLES:
Pull the image 'gcr.io/google-containers/pause:1.0' from the
docker registry:

  $ docker -- pull gcr.io/google-containers/pause:1.0

Push the image 'gcr.io/example-org/example-image:latest' to our
private docker registry.

  $ docker -- push gcr.io/example-org/example-image:latest

Configure authentication, then simply use docker:

  $ docker --authorize-only

  $ docker push gcr.io/example-org/example-image:latest

feedback.capsule: Provide feedback to the Google Cloud SDK team.
feedback.description:
The Google Cloud SDK team offers support through a number of channels:

* Google Cloud SDK Issue Tracker
* Stack Overflow "#gcloud" tag
* google-cloud-dev Google group

This command lists the available channels and facilitates getting help through
one of them by opening a web browser to the relevant page, possibly with
information relevant to the current install and configuration pre-populated in
form fields on that page.

set-iam-policy.capsule: Set IAM policy for a service account.
set-iam-policy.description:
This command replaces the existing IAM policy for a service account, given
an IAM-ACCOUNT and a file encoded in JSON or YAML that contains the IAM
policy. If the given policy file specifies an "etag" value, then the
replacement will succeed only if the policy already in place matches that
etag. (An etag obtained via $ gcloud iam service-accounts get-iam-policy will
prevent the replacement if the policy for the service account has been
subsequently updated.) A policy file that does not contain an etag value will
replace any existing policy for the service account.
set-iam-policy.name: set-iam-policy

positionals.description: The service account whose policy to set.
positionals.name: account

positionals.description: Path to a local JSON or YAML formatted file containing a valid policy.
positionals.name: policy-file

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command replaces the existing IAM policy for a service account, given
an IAM-ACCOUNT and a file encoded in JSON or YAML that contains the IAM
policy. If the given policy file specifies an "etag" value, then the
replacement will succeed only if the policy already in place matches that
etag. (An etag obtained via $ gcloud iam service-accounts get-iam-policy will
prevent the replacement if the policy for the service account has been
subsequently updated.) A policy file that does not contain an etag value will
replace any existing policy for the service account.
sections.EXAMPLES:
The following command will read an IAM policy defined in a JSON file
'policy.json' and set it for a service account with identifier 'my-iam-account@somedomain.com'

  $ set-iam-policy my-iam-account@somedomain.com policy.json


See https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/managing-policies for details
of the policy file format and contents.

sections.DESCRIPTION:
Initialize or reinitialize gcloud.

init launches an interactive Getting Started workflow for gcloud.
It replaces `gcloud auth login` as the recommended command to execute
after you install the Cloud SDK. init performs the following
setup steps:

  - Authorizes gcloud and other SDK tools to access Google Cloud
    Platform using your user account credentials, or lets you select
    from accounts whose credentials are already available. init
    uses the same browser-based authorization flow as
    `gcloud auth login`.
  - Sets properties in a gcloud configuration, including the current
    project and the default Google Compute Engine region and zone.

Most users run init to get started with gcloud. You can use
subsequent init invocations to create new gcloud configurations
or to reinitialize existing configurations.  See `gcloud topic
configurations` for additional information.

Properties set by `gcloud init` are local and persistent. They are
not affected by remote changes to your project. For instance, the
default Compute Engine zone in your configuration remains stable,
even if you or another user changes the project-level default zone in
the Cloud Platform Console.  You can resync your configuration at any
time by rerunning `gcloud init`.

(Available since version 0.9.79. Run $ gcloud --version to see which
version you are running.)

This command lists all the configurations for a given service by ID.

To get more detailed information about a specific configuration, run:

  $ configs describe

To list the configurations for a service named `my-service`, run:

  $ list --service my-service

sections.DESCRIPTION:
Deletes a service from Google Service Management.

Services that are deleted will be retained in the system for 30 days.
If a deleted service is still within this retention window, it can be
undeleted with the undelete command.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To delete a service named `my-service`, run:

  $ delete my-service

To run the same command asynchronously (non-blocking), run:

  $ delete my-service --async

--async.description: Don't wait for the operation to complete.
--async.name: --async

positionals.description: The service configuration file (or files) containing the API specification to upload. Proto Descriptors, Open API (Swagger) specifications, and Google Service Configuration files in JSON and YAML formats are acceptable.
positionals.name: service-config-file

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command is used to deploy a service configuration for a service
to Google Service Management. As input, it takes one or more paths
to service configurations that should be uploaded. These configuration
files can be Proto Descriptors, Open API (Swagger) specifications,
or Google Service Configuration files in JSON or YAML formats.

If a service name is present in multiple configuration files (given
in the `host` field in OpenAPI specifications or the `name` field in
Google Service Configuration files), the first one will take precedence.

This command will block until deployment is complete unless the
`--async` flag is passed.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To deploy a single Open API service configuration, run:

  $ deploy ~/my_app/openapi.json

To run the deployment asynchronously (non-blocking), run:

  $ deploy ~/my_app/openapi.json --async

To deploy a service config with a Proto, run:

  $ deploy ~/my_app/service-config.yaml ~/my_app/service-protos.pb

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command disables a previously-enabled service for consumption.

To see a list of the enabled services for a project, run:

  $ service-management list --enabled

More information on listing services can be found at:
https://cloud.google.com/service-management/list-services and on
disabling a service at:
https://cloud.google.com/service-management/enable-disable#disabling_services
sections.EXAMPLES:
To disable a service called `my-consumed-service` for the active
project, run:

  $ disable my-consumed-service

To run the same command asynchronously (non-blocking), run:

  $ disable my-consumed-service --async

This command enables a service for consumption for a project.

To see a list of available services for a project, run:

  $ service-management list --available

More information on listing services can be found at:
https://cloud.google.com/service-management/list-services and on
enabling a service at:
https://cloud.google.com/service-management/enable-disable#enabling_services

To enable a service called `my-consumed-service` on the current

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command lists the services that are produced, enabled, or
available to be enabled by a project. You can choose the mode in
which the command will list services by using exactly one of the
`--produced`, `--enabled`, or `--available` flags.
`--produced` is the default.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To list the services the current project produces, run:

  $ list --produced

To list the services the current project has enabled for consumption,
run:

  $ list --enabled

To list the services the current project can enable for consumption,
run:

  $ list --available

This command will return information about an operation given the name
of that operation.

The amount of information inside an operation can be very large, so by
default, only a summary is returned. If you want the entire operation
resource, you can include the `--full` flag.

Note that the `operations/` prefix of the operation name is optional
and may be omitted.

To describe an operation resource named
`operations/serviceConfigs.my-service.1`, run:

  $ describe serviceConfigs.my-service.1

To get the full operation resource, run:

  $ describe serviceConfigs.my-service.1 --full

Services that are deleted will be retained in the system for 30 days.

undeleted with this command.

sections.DESCRIPTION:
This command clones git repository for the currently active
Google Cloud Platform project into the specified folder in the
current directory.
sections.EXAMPLES:
To use the default Google Cloud repository for development, use the
following commands. We recommend that you use your project name as
TARGET_DIR to make it apparent which directory is used for which
project. We also recommend to clone the repository named 'default'
since it is automatically created for each project, and its
contents can be browsed and edited in the Developers Console.

  $ gcloud init
  $ gcloud source repos clone default TARGET_DIR
  $ cd TARGET_DIR
  ... create/edit files and create one or more commits ...
  $ git push origin master

instances.capsule: Provide commands for managing Cloud SQL instances.

clone.description:
*clone* creates a clone of the Cloud SQL instance. The source and the
destination instances must be in the same project. The clone once created
will be an independent Cloud SQL instance.

The binary log coordinates, if specified, act as the point up to which the
source instance is cloned. If not specified, the source instance is
cloned up to the most recent binary log coordinates at the time the command is
executed.

## EXAMPLES

To clone a source instance to the most recent binary log coordinates:

  $ clone instance-foo instance-bar

or to clone at specific binary log coordinates:

  $ clone instance-foo instance-bar --bin-log-file-name mysql-bin.000020 --bin-log-position 170

--async.description: Don't wait for the operation to complete.
--async.name: --async

--bin-log-file-name.description: Binary log file for the source instance.
--bin-log-file-name.name: --bin-log-file-name

--bin-log-position.description: Position within the binary log file that represents the point up to which the source is cloned.
--bin-log-position.name: --bin-log-position

clone.name: clone

positionals.description: Cloud SQL instance ID of the source.
positionals.name: source

positionals.description: Cloud SQL instance ID of the clone.
positionals.name: destination
